For it's time, it was a very gritty movie and very close to the first movie I ever say in color. It gets a 10/10 from me. It is a lot better than some of the trash getting awards today.

Author: 7 June 2012
Review_Url: "Gone With the Wind" is a beautiful romance film, directed by David Selznick. It is an amazing film adaptation of Margaret Mitchell's immortal novel. "Gone With the Wind" is film epic describing the events of the Civil War and subsequent years. The film based on the history of the beautiful, selfless love, confrontation between two lovers, who don't want to sacrifice their pride and open up their feelings to each other. The main characters are Scarlett O'Hara, Rhett Butler, Ashley Wilkes and Melanie Hamilton. Scarlett was played by Vivien Leigh, Rhett by Clark Gable, Ashley by Leslie Howard, and Melanie by Olivia de Havilland. Scarlett is in love with Ashley since childhood, she loves him devotedly and selflessly. She saves Melanie (Ashley's wife) and her son, cares for them, in spite of her own feelings. Scarlett builds her life against all customs and traditions. The values formed since childhoods are transformed into new. She understands it's impossible to return old world with old ideals and values, but it's possible to build a new life. Scarlett pursue the dream of Ashley, unaware that her happiness is very close. Rhett Butler is a man with scandalous reputation. He loves Scarlett, but disguises his feelings, because he was afraid to be rejected. Rhett is a representative of the new era, he sees the sough is doomed, watching the collapse of the old world, but he doesn't build any illusions and believes in new life. This film is well worth seeing. There are a lot of memorable moments: farewell of Rhett and Scarlett on the eve of the collapse of Atlanta, hospital, Rhett's proposal, the death of Melanie and Bony, an open end. Film is striking: breads of depicted life, a beautiful love story, wonderful pictures of nature, pathetic music, and unforgettable end!!! This is a very exciting film. The acting is above all praise! "Gone With the Wind" is the most magnificent picture ever!

Author: 10 June 2012
Review: Taking care of Family or Taking Care of Self: What was Scarlett's real motivation?
Review_Url: I am currently a student taking a course in The Art of Film at a community college in Dayton, Ohio. One of the assignments is to write a post or add to a post of a movie of our choice. I chose Gone with the Wind because it has to be one of my favorite movies. Katie "Scarlett" O'Hara-Hamilton-Kennedy-Butler has to be one of the best female roles in film to me. When she is depicted before the Civil War, she is immediately shown with two beaus at her house on a beautiful summer's day. When the two young men start speaking of war she explains that talk of war bores her. As the two beaus continue to ask about war, Scarlett begins to retreat into the house. The men suddenly come to their senses and apologize, while saying they will not talk about war anymore. It is here we see Scarlett does get her way. As they change the subject to the barbecue at the Wilkes', a neighbor's plantation, she is stunned to find out that the love of life is marrying his cousin (just have to add that I am glad people do not do that anymore)! Scarlett immediately storms off in anger and confusion, wondering how that could be if Ashley, her crush, loves her. While storming off she is told by her "Mammy" that it was rude to leave the company standing there without asking them to stay for dinner and that she needs a shawl on her shoulders if she is going to be out in the evening. Scarlett yells back that she is waiting for her father to get home from the Wilkes', to get the inside information on what is really going on. The movie takes place in the south, before, during, and after the Civil War era, when slavery was the largest problem of the United States. To Scarlett, war was a stupid problem that she never wanted to talk about; she was happy having every beau in the county sit next to her at a barbecue and drool all over her. Even though her love for Ashley never wavered, she married three men throughout her life as a means to survive. I do not think she was just trying to survive for herself, I think she showed that she had heart and truly cared for her family when she married Frank Kennedy. Knowing that Frank was Suellen's beau, I think she figured once Suellen and Frank were married that they would leave and would no longer have to worry about Tara and the rest of the family. Therefore, Scarlett married Frank and paid the taxes on Tara so the family would have a home. A selfish person would not have done that, a person with no morals might have.

Review: Gone with the WInd is the best movie in existence
Review_Url: Gone with the Wind has all the necessary requirements for a classic, brilliant journey needed for the best movie ever created. It has all the elements to satisfy any movie buff. Author: 17 December 2004
Review: Gable should have gotten the Academy Award for this one....
Review_Url: I first saw GWTW at an early age and remembered that I thought Gable looked like an old man and why would anyone be attracted to him -- HA! I am now in my thirties, and this is my favorite movie of all time. I have seen, read about, and seriously dreamed about this movie for some time. I have seen it aleast 50-75 times and I can find no flaws. From casting, which is incredible and impossible to imagine any of the main characters being played by anyone else, to filming, which if you get the new 4 DVD set out you will see just how incredible it was to film this movie, I find absolutely no flaws with this spectacular movie. The storyline is, as is should be, written for word, right out of Mitchell's book. I do admit that the book is incredible and some of the storyline I wish had made it into the movie, ie. Scarlett's children. I would have liked to have seen her in the early mother role with a son that could barely speak his own name he was so timid of her! Back to the movie...if you are of southern descent and you have not seen this movie, someone should spank you! If you are northern and not seen this movie, then you should so you know how most of the south still feels about you. I have yet to met a northerner that was not 'out of the norm' of this movie. It pegs them to a tee! (And I've met plenty!) A movie with a wonderful story, wonderful scenery and a wonderful cast! I, too, do not believe that there was an American actress at that time that could have surpassed Leigh's performance. She is truly magnificent. My favorite line of her's is when ole Kennedy has died and she has been drinking brandy and Rhett comes to call on her and she see's him out her window and hiccups and say "It's Rhett". And then pretties herself up with cologne with Rhett smells right away and says " Scarlett, you should never drink alone, people aways find out and it ruins their reputation!" So true and yet so funny! The movie is wonderful, beginning to end, and if you haven't seen it, it's at least worth a Sunday afternoon of your time. Beautifully filmed, beautifully portrayed. My 8 year son now knows just about every line, he's loves this movie. His favorite line is when Mammie is putting Mr. Kennedy pants in the "boilin' pot", he doubles over every time he hears her say that. Yes, I know some black people believe this is a racist film and I'm sorry they feel that way. I don't take it upon myself to say it is or it isn't but that's the way it was only 'glorified'. I think ALL Americans should all be proud of the performances and at least HATTIE was given the first 'Supporting Actress Award" for a black performer. She was excellent! NO ONE could have made a better performance. If you do research on the time she spent on GWTW you will get a good perspective of what she thought of the role and what she wanted to bring to the picture. My only disappoint was that Clark Gable did not receive an Academy Award for this picture...he was so good that everyone thought he wasn't really acting, he was just himself. I am a die-hard GABLE fan, and, yes, this part was made for him but he still had to act the part. I still believe he was robbed!! Studio would not let him get the Academy Award! That sucked!If you are not a Gable fan, please check out some of his other flics! He is still the best of the BEST! But if you are still here for GWTW , don't miss the opportunity to see the best picture of all time!And it is, it truly is!!

Author: 29 January 2015
Review: My personal opinion of the movie
Review_Url: Although this epic romantic melodrama is undoubtedly one of the most popular and beloved motion pictures ever to grace the silver screen, it is also arguably the most overrated. Gone with the Wind is a very good movie, perhaps bordering on being great, but its subject matter and running time. Gone with the Wind is, simply put, a tale of two halves. The movie is divided by an intermission into a pair of roughly-equal segments. Then first, which is brilliant and consistently captivating, covers the time period of the Civil War, ending during Sherman's march through Atlanta. The post-intermission half, which dishes out the suds, picks up at the end of the Civil War and concludes about eight years later. This portion of Gone with the Wind, spins its wheels frequently. Theatrically, Gone with the Wind is an entirely different experience from its small-screen counterpart; some of the second-half narrative tedium is effaced by the glorious visuals. With a restored three- strip. Gone with the Wind has one of the best-known story lines of any film. Is Scarlett O'Hara (Vivien Leigh), the spoiled, manipulative daughter of an Irish immigrant plantation owner (Thomas Mitchell). Scarlett has two sisters, but she is by far the most spirited of the three O'Hara girls, and her father, seeing her as his successor, teaches her lessons about the importance of the land. Scarlett is secretly in love with Ashley Wilkes (Leslie Howard), who is about to marry the gentle, demure Melanie Hamilton (Olivia De Havilland). When Scarlett confesses her love to Ashley, he admits his feelings for her, but notes that Melanie will make a much better wife. Immediately after this meeting, Scarlett has her first encounter with the irrepressible Rhett Butler (Clark Gable), the cynical, smart hero who eventually falls in love with her. They are two headstrong likes who simultaneously repel and attract one another. Ultimately, when Rhett has finally had enough, he walks out of her life to her plaintive query about what she's supposed to do without him. The pre-intermission portion of Gone with the Wind, which runs about 115 minutes, is glorious from both a visual and an emotional standpoint. It's a grand tale of love and loss in the midst of this country's most bitter war. Most importantly, it shows Scarlett's development from a vain, spoiled brat into a hardened, determined young woman. Her relationship with Rhett is there, but kept carefully in the background. There is sadness, humor, and a number of breathtaking shots of Scarlett silhouetted against a reddish sunset. Gone with the Wind stands as a romantic monument to the Old South -- an homage to an era and a lifestyle long gone. To date, no film has sold more box-office tickets than Gone with the Wind. Domestically, the tally almost doubles that for the phenomenally-popular Titanic. Of course, when the movie was first released, it wasn't just another motion picture -- it was a spectacle, an event. Even though the habits of movie- goers have changed over the years, it's easy to see why this film provoked such an outpouring of praise and adulation during its initial release, and why its stature has grown with the passage of decades. Gone with the Wind has flaws, but it's still undeniably a classic and a legend.

Author: 15 July 2006
Review: The Best Movie in the World
Review_Url: This is an extremely classic movie that everyone should see. The acting is excellent and the story is unforgettable! "Gone With the Wind" completed me when I watched it. Clark Gable is very beautiful as well, which makes the movie so much more enjoyable. Following Scarlett through her life, we start at the beginning of the Civil War. With the theme of sacrifice and love, it makes it a wonderful classic. The love between Rhett and Scarlett is one that I can only imagine; the beauty is unforgettable and indescribable. If you are having questions about whether to watch this movie, take them back and forget about it. Watch the movie, you will be changed! I highly recommend it to anyone yearning to see a spectacular film.
